sp.p: I would like you to hear what he says of you , Mr. Halvey . Pitch and toss , he says .

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: Robbery , he says .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Delane
sp.p: Robbery of a church .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: He has had a bad name long enough . Let him go to a reformatory now .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Clinging to Hyacinth .Save me , save me ! I 'm a poor boy trying to knock out a way of living ; I 'll be destroyed if I go to a reformatory .Kneels and clings to Hyacinth 's knees .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I 'll save you easy enough .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Do n't let me be gaoled !

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I am going to tell them .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: I 'm a poor orphan ——

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Will you let me speak ?

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: I 'll get no more chance in the world ——

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Sure I 'm trying to free you ——

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: It will be tasked to me always .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Be quiet , can n't you .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Do n't you desert me !

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Will you be silent ?

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Take it on yourself .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I will if you 'll let me .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Tell them you did it .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I am going to do that .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Tell them it was you got in at the window .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I will ! I will !

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Say it was you robbed the box .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I 'll say it ! I 'll say it !

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: It being open !

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Let me tell , let me tell .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: Of all that was in it .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I 'll tell them that .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: And gave it to me .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Putting hand on his mouth and dragging him up .Will you stop and let me speak ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: We can n't be wasting time . Give him here to me .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I can n't do that . He must be let alone .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Seizing him .He 'll be let alone in the lock-up .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: He must not be brought there .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I 'll let no man get him off .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I will get him off .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: You will not !

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Do you think to buy him off ?

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: I will buy him off with my own confession .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: And what will that be ?

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: It was I robbed the church .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: That is likely indeed !

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Let him go , and take me . I tell you I did it .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: It would take witnesses to prove that .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Pointing to Fardy .He will be witness .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: O ! Mr. Halvey , I would not wish to do that . Get me off and I will say nothing .

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: Sure you must . You will be put on oath in the court .

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: I will not ! I will not ! All the world knows I do n't understand the nature of an oath !

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: Coming forward .Is it blind ye all are ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Delane
sp.p: What are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: Is it fools ye all are ?

sp.speaker: Miss Joyce
sp.p: Speak for yourself .

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: Is it idiots ye all are ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Mind who you 're talking to .

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: Seizing Hyacinth 's hands .Ca n't you see ? Ca n't you hear ? Where are your wits ? Was ever such a thing seen in this town ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Delane
sp.p: Say out what you have to say .

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: A walking saint he is !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Delane
sp.p: Maybe so .

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: The preserver of the poor ! Talk of the holy martyrs ! They are nothing at all to what he is ! Will you look at him ! To save that poor boy he is going ! To take the blame on himself he is going ! To say he himself did the robbery he is going ! Before the magistrate he is going ! To gaol he is going ! Taking the blame on his own head ! Putting the sin on his own shoulders ! Letting on to have done a robbery ! Telling a lie — that it may be forgiven him — to his own injury ! Doing all that I tell you to save the character of a miserable slack lad , that rose in poverty .

body.stage: Murmur of admiration from all .

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: Now , what do you say ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Pressing his hand .Mr. Halvey , you have given us all a lesson . To please you , I will make no information against the boy .Shakes him and helps him up .I will put back the half-crown in the poor-box next Sunday .To Fardy .What have you to say to your benefactor ?

sp.speaker: Fardy
sp.p: I 'm obliged to you , Mr. Halvey . You behaved very decent to me , very decent indeed . I 'll never let a word be said against you if I live to be a hundred years .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Wiping eyes with a blue handkerchief .I will tell it at the meeting . It will be a great encouragement to them to build up their character . I 'll tell it to the priest and he taking the chair ——

sp.speaker: Hyacinth
sp.p: O stop , will you ——

sp.speaker: Mr. Quirke
sp.p: The chair . It 's in the chair he himself should be . It 's in a chair we will put him now . It 's to chair him through the streets we will . Sure he 'll be an example and a blessing to the whole of the town .Seizes Halvey and seats him in chair .Now , Sergeant , give a hand . Here , Fardy .

body.stage: They all lift the chair with Halvey in it , wildly protesting .

lg.l: : Come along now to the Courthouse . Three cheers for
Hyacinth Halvey ! Hip ! hip ! hoora !

body.stage: Cheers heard in the distance as the curtain drops .

set.p: Scene : Side of a quay in a seaport town . Some posts and chains . A large barrel . Enter three policemen . Moonlight .

body.stage: Sergeant , who is older than the others , crosses the stage to right and looks down steps . The others put down a pastepot and unroll a bundle of placards .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: I think this would be a good place to put up a notice .He points to barrel .

sp.speaker: Policeman X
sp.p: Better ask him .Calls to Sergt .Will this be a good place for a placard ?

body.stage: No answer .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: Will we put up a notice here on the barrel ?No answer .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: There 's a flight of steps here that leads to the water . This is a place that should be minded well . If he got down here , his friends might have a boat to meet him ; they might send it in here from outside .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: Would the barrel be a good place to put a notice up ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: It might ; you can put it there .

body.stage: They paste the notice up .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Reading it .Dark hair — dark eyes , smooth face , height five feet five — there 's not much to take hold of in that — It 's a pity I had no chance of seeing him before he broke out of gaol . They say he 's a wonder , that it 's he makes all the plans for the whole organization . There is n't another man in Ireland would have broken gaol the way he did . He must have some friends among the gaolers .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: A hundred pounds is little enough for the Government to offer for him . You may be sure any man in the force that takes him will get promotion .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I 'll mind this place myself . I would n't wonder at all if he came this way . He might come slipping along therepoints to side of quay, and his friends might be waiting for him therepoints down steps, and once he got away it 's little chance we 'd have of finding him ; it 's maybe under a load of kelp he 'd be in a fishing boat , and not one to help a married man that wants it to the reward .

sp.speaker: Policeman X
sp.p: And if we get him itself , nothing but abuse on our heads for it from the people , and maybe from our own relations .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Well , we have to do our duty in the force . Have n't we the whole country depending on us to keep law and order ? It 's those that are down would be up and those that are up would be down , if it was n't for us . Well , hurry on , you have plenty of other places to placard yet , and come back here then to me . You can take the lantern . Do n't be too long now . It 's very lonesome here with nothing but the moon .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: It 's a pity we can n't stop with you . The Government should have brought more police into the town , with him in gaol , and at assize time too . Well , good luck to your watch .

body.stage: They go out .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Walks up and down once or twice and looks at placard .A hundred pounds and promotion sure . There must be a great deal of spending in a hundred pounds . It 's a pity some honest man not to be the better of that .

body.stage: A ragged man appears at left and tries to slip past . Sergeant suddenly turns .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I 'm a poor ballad-singer , your honour . I thought to sell some of theseholds out bundle of balladsto the sailors .He goes on .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Stop ! Did n't I tell you to stop ? You can n't go on there .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Oh , very well . It 's a hard thing to be poor . All the world 's against the poor !

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Who are you ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: You 'd be as wise as myself if I told you , but I do n't mind . I 'm one Jimmy Walsh , a ballad-singer .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Jimmy Walsh ? I do n't know that name .

lg.l: : Ah , sure , they know it well enough in Ennis . Were you ever in
Ennis , sergeant ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: What brought you here ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Sure , it 's to the assizes I came , thinking I might make a few shillings here or there . It 's in the one train with the judges I came .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Well , if you came so far , you may as well go farther , for you 'll walk out of this .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I will , I will ; I 'll just go on where I was going .Goes towards steps .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Come back from those steps ; no one has leave to pass down them to-night .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I 'll just sit on the top of the steps till I see will some sailor buy a ballad off me that would give me my supper . They do be late going back to the ship . It 's often I saw them in Cork carried down the quay in a hand-cart .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Move on , I tell you . I wo n't have any one lingering about the quay to-night .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Well , I 'll go . It 's the poor have the hard life ! Maybe yourself might like one , sergeant . Here 's a good sheet now .Turns one over .“ Content and a pipe ” — that 's not much . “ The Peeler and the goat ” — you would n't like that . “ Johnny Hart ” — that 's a lovely song .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Move on .

lg.l: Ah , wait till you hear it .
There was a rich farmer 's daughter lived near the town of Ross ;
She courted a Highland soldier , his name was Johnny Hart ;
Says the mother to her daughter , “ I 'll go distracted mad
If you marry that Highland soldier dressed up in Highland plaid . ”

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Stop that noise .

body.stage: Man wraps up his ballads and shuffles towards the steps

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Sure you told me to be going , and I am going .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Do n't be a fool . I did n't tell you to go that way ; I told you to go back to the town .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Back to the town , is it ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Taking him by the shoulder and shoving him before him .Here , I 'll show you the way . Be off with you . What are you stopping for ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Who has been keeping his eye on the notice , points to it .I think I know what you 're waiting for , sergeant .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: What 's that to you ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And I know well the man you 're waiting for — I know him well — I 'll be going .

body.stage: He shuffles on .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: You know him ? Come back here . What sort is he ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Come back is it , sergeant ? Do you want to have me killed ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Why do you say that ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Never mind . I 'm going . I would n't be in your shoes if the reward was ten times as much .Goes on off stage to leftNot if it was ten times as much .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Rushing after him .Come back here , come back .Drags him back .What sort is he ? Where did you see him ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I saw him in my own place , in the County Clare . I tell you you would n't like to be looking at him . You 'd be afraid to be in the one place with him . There is n't a weapon he does n't know the use of , and as to strength , his muscles are as hard as that boardslaps barrel

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Is he as bad as that ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: He is then .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Do you tell me so ?

lg.l: : There was a poor man in our place , a sergeant from
Ballyvaughan .— It was with a lump of stone he did it .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I never heard of that .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And you would n't , sergeant . It 's not everything that happens gets into the papers . And there was a policeman in plain clothes , too .... It is in Limerick he was .... It was after the time of the attack on the police barrack at Kilmallock .... Moonlight ... just like this ... waterside .... Nothing was known for certain .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Do you say so ? It 's a terrible county to belong to .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: That 's so , indeed ! You might be standing there , looking out that way , thinking you saw him coming up this side of the quaypoints, and he might be coming up this other sidepoints, and he 'd be on you before you knew where you were .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: It 's a whole troop of police they ought to put here to stop a man like that .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: But if you 'd like me to stop with you , I could be looking down this side . I could be sitting up here on this barrel .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: And you know him well , too ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I 'd know him a mile off , sergeant .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: But you would n't want to share the reward ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Is it a poor man like me , that has to be going the roads and singing in fairs , to have the name on him that he took a reward ? But you do n't want me . I 'll be safer in the town .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Well , you can stop .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Getting up on barrel .All right , sergeant . I wonder , now , you 're not tired out , sergeant , walking up and down the way you are .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: If I 'm tired I 'm used to it .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: You might have hard work before you to-night yet . Take it easy while you can . There 's plenty of room up here on the barrel , and you see farther when you 're higher up .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Maybe so .Gets up beside him on barrel , facing right . They sit back to back , looking different ways .You made me feel a bit queer with the way you talked .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Give me a match , sergeanthe gives it and man lights pipe; take a draw yourself ? It 'll quiet you . Wait now till I give you a light , but you need n't turn round . Do n't take your eye off the quay for the life of you .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Never fear , I wo n't .Lights pipe . They both smoke .Indeed it 's a hard thing to be in the force , out at night and no thanks for it , for all the danger we 're in . And it 's little we get but abuse from the people , and no choice but to obey our orders , and never asked when a man is sent into danger , if you are a married man with a family .

lg.l: As through the hills I walked to view the hills and shamrock plain ,
I stood awhile where nature smiles to view the rocks and streams ,
On a matron fair I fixed my eyes beneath a fertile vale ,
As she sang her song it was on the wrong of poor old Granuaile .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Stop that ; that 's no song to be singing in these times .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Ah , sergeant , I was only singing to keep my heart up . It sinks when I think of him . To think of us two sitting here , and he creeping up the quay , maybe , to get to us .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Are you keeping a good lookout ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I am ; and for no reward too . Am n't I the foolish man ? But when I saw a man in trouble , I never could help trying to get him out of it . What 's that ? Did something hit me ?

body.stage: Rubs his heart .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Patting him on the shoulder .You will get your reward in heaven .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I know that , I know that , sergeant , but life is precious .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Well , you can sing if it gives you more courage .

lg.l: Her head was bare , her hands and feet with iron bands were bound ,
Her pensive strain and plaintive wail mingles with the evening gale ,
And the song she sang with mournful air , I am old Granuaile .
Her lips so sweet that monarchs kissed ....

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: That 's not it .... “ Her gown she wore was stained with gore . ” ... That 's it — you missed that .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: You 're right , sergeant , so it is ; I missed it .Repeats line .But to think of a man like you knowing a song like that .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: There 's many a thing a man might know and might not have any wish for .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Now , I daresay , sergeant , in your youth , you used to be sitting up on a wall , the way you are sitting up on this barrel now , and the other lads beside you , and you singing “ Granuaile ” ?...

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I did then .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And the “ Shan Bhean Bhocht ” ?...

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I did then .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And the “ Green on the Cape ? ”

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: That was one of them .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And maybe the man you are watching for to-night used to be sitting on the wall , when he was young , and singing those same songs .... It 's a queer world ....

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Whisht !... I think I see something coming .... It 's only a dog .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And is n't it a queer world ?... Maybe it 's one of the boys you used to be singing with that time you will be arresting to-day or to-morrow , and sending into the dock ....

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: That 's true indeed .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: And maybe one night , after you had been singing , if the other boys had told you some plan they had , some plan to free the country , you might have joined with them ... and maybe it is you might be in trouble now .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Well , who knows but I might ? I had a great spirit in those days .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: It 's a queer world , sergeant , and it 's little any mother knows when she sees her child creeping on the floor what might happen to it before it has gone through its life , or who will be who in the end .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: That 's a queer thought now , and a true thought . Wait now till I think it out .... If it was n't for the sense I have , and for my wife and family , and for me joining the force the time I did , it might be myself now would be after breaking gaol and hiding in the dark , and it might be him that 's hiding in the dark and that got out of gaol would be sitting up where I am on this barrel .... And it might be myself would be creeping up trying to make my escape from himself , and it might be himself would be keeping the law , and myself would be breaking it , and myself would be trying maybe to put a bullet in his head , or to take up a lump of a stone the way you said he did ... no , that myself did .... Oh !Gasps . After a pause .What 's that ?Grasps man 's arm .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Jumps off barrel and listens , looking out over water .It 's nothing , sergeant .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I thought it might be a boat . I had a notion there might be friends of his coming about the quays with a boat .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Sergeant , I am thinking it was with the people you were , and not with the law you were , when you were a young man .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Well , if I was foolish then , that time 's gone .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Maybe , sergeant , it comes into your head sometimes , in spite of your belt and your tunic , that it might have been as well for you to have followed Granuaile .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: It 's no business of yours what I think .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Maybe , sergeant , you 'll be on the side of the country yet .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Gets off barrel .Do n't talk to me like that . I have my duties and I know them .Looks round .That was a boat ; I hear the oars .

body.stage: Goes to the steps and looks down .

lg.l: O , then , tell me , Shawn O'Farrell ,
Where the gathering is to be .
In the old spot by the river
Right well known to you and me !

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Stop that ! Stop that , I tell you !

lg.l: One word more , for signal token ,
Whistle up the marching tune ,
With your pike upon your shoulder ,
At the Rising of the Moon .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: If you do n't stop that , I 'll arrest you .

body.stage: A whistle from below answers , repeating the air .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: That 's a signal .Stands between him and steps .You must not pass this way .... Step farther back .... Who are you ? You are no ballad-singer .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: You need n't ask who I am ; that placard will tell you .Points to placard .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: You are the man I am looking for .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Takes off hat and wig . Sergeant seizes them .I am . There 's a hundred pounds on my head . There is a friend of mine below in a boat . He knows a safe place to bring me to .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Looking still at hat and wig .It 's a pity ! It 's a pity . You deceived me . You deceived me well .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I am a friend of Granuaile . There is a hundred pounds on my head .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: It 's a pity , it 's a pity !

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Will you let me pass , or must I make you let me ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I am in the force . I will not let you pass .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: I thought to do it with my tongue .Puts hand in breast .What is that ?

body.stage: Voice of Policeman X outside :) Here , this is where we left him .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: It 's my comrades coming .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: You wo n't betray me ... the friend of Granuaile .Slips behind barrel .

body.stage: Voice of Policeman B :) That was the last of the placards .

sp.speaker: Policeman X
sp.p: As they come in .If he makes his escape it wo n't be unknown he 'll make it .

body.stage: Sergeant puts hat and wig behind his back .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: Did any one come this way ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: After a pause .No one .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: No one at all ?

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: No one at all .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: We had no orders to go back to the station ; we can stop along with you .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I do n't want you . There is nothing for you to do here .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: You bade us to come back here and keep watch with you .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I 'd sooner be alone . Would any man come this way and you making all that talk ? It is better the place to be quiet .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: Well , we 'll leave you the lantern anyhow .Hands it to him .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: I do n't want it . Bring it with you .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: You might want it . There are clouds coming up and you have the darkness of the night before you yet . I 'll leave it over here on the barrel .Goes to barrel .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Bring it with you I tell you . No more talk .

sp.speaker: Policeman B
sp.p: Well , I thought it might be a comfort to you . I often think when I have it in my hand and can be flashing it about into every dark cornerdoing sothat it 's the same as being beside the fire at home , and the bits of bogwood blazing up now and again .

body.stage: Flashes it about , now on the barrel , now on Sergeant .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Furious .Be off the two of you , yourselves and your lantern !

body.stage: They go out . Man comes from behind barrel . He and Sergeant stand looking at one another .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: What are you waiting for ?

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: For my hat , of course , and my wig . You would n't wish me to get my death of cold ?

body.stage: Sergeant gives them .

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Going towards steps .Well , good-night , comrade , and thank you . You did me a good turn to-night , and I 'm obliged to you . Maybe I 'll be able to do as much for you when the small rise up and the big fall down ... when we all change places at the Risingwaves his hand and disappearsof the Moon .

sp.speaker: Sergeant
sp.p: Turning his back to audience and reading placard .A hundred pounds reward ! A hundred pounds !Turns towards audience .I wonder , now , am I as great a fool as I think I am ?

body.stage: Curtain .

body.head: THE JACKDAW
PERSONS
body.stage: JOSEPH NESTOR An Army Pensioner . MICHAEL COONEY A Farmer . MRS. BRODERICK A Small Shopkeeper . TOMMY NALLY A Pauper . SIBBY FAHY An Orange Seller . TIMOTHY WARD A Process Server .

set.p: Scene : Interior of a small general shop at Cloon . Mrs. Broderick sitting down . Tommy Nally sitting eating an orange Sibby has given him . Sibby , with basket on her arm , is looking out of door .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: The people are gathering to the door of the Court . The Magistrates will be coming there before long . Here is Timothy Ward coming up the street .

sp.speaker: Timothy Ward
sp.p: Coming to door .Did you get that summons I left here for you ere yesterday , Mrs. Broderick ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I believe it 's there in under the canister .Takes it out .It had my mind tossed looking at it there before me . I know well what is in it if I made no fist of reading it itself . It 's no wonder with all I had to go through if the reading and writing got scattered on me .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: You know it is on this day you have to appear in the Court ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: It is n't easy to forget that , though indeed it is hard for me to be keeping anything in my head these times , but maybe remembering to-morrow the thing I was saying to-day .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Up to one o'clock the magistrates will be able to attend to you , ma'am , before they will go out eating their meal .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Have n't I the mean , begrudging creditors now that would put me into the Court ? Sure it 's a terrible thing to go in it and to be bound to speak nothing but the truth . When people would meet with you after , they would remember your face in the Court . What way would they be certain was it in or outside of the dock ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: It is not in the dock you will be put this time . And there will be no bodily harm done to you , but to seize your furniture and your goods . It 's best for me to be going there myself and not to be wasting my time .Goes out .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Many a one taking my goods on credit and I seeing their face no more . But nothing would satisfy the people of this district . Sure the great God Himself when He came down could n't please everybody .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: I am thinking you were talking of some friend , ma'am , might be apt to be coming to your aid .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Well able he is to do it if the Lord would but put it in his mind . Is n't it a strange thing the goods of this world to shut up the heart of a brother from his own , the same as Esau and Jacob , and he having a good farm of land in the County Limerick . It is what I heard that in that place the grass does be as thick as grease .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: I suppose , ma'am , you wrote giving him an account of your case ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Sure , Mr. Nestor , the dear man , has his fingers wore away writing for me , and I telling him all he had or had not to say . At Christmas I wrote , and at Little Christmas , and at St. Brigit 's Day , and on the Feast of St. Patrick , and after that again such time as I had news of the summons being about to be served . And you may ask Mrs. Delane at the Post Office am I telling any lie saying I got no word or answer at all .... It 's long since I saw him , but it is the way he used to be , his eyes on kippeens and some way suspicious in his heart ; a dark weighty tempered man .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: A person to be crabbed and he young , it is not likely he will grow kind at the latter end .

sp.speaker: Tommy Nally
sp.p: That is no less than true now . There are crabbed people and suspicious people to be met with in every place . It is much that I got a pass from the Workhouse this day , the Master making sure when I asked it that I had in my pocket the means of getting drink .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: It would maybe be best to go join you in the Workhouse , Tommy Nally , when I am out of this , than to go walking the world from end to end .

sp.speaker: Tommy Nally
sp.p: Ah , do n't be saying that , ma'am ; sure you could n't be happy within those walls if you had the whole world . Clean outside , but very hard within . No rank but all mixed together , the good , the middling and the bad , the well reared and the rough .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Sure I 'm not asking to go in it . You could never be as stiff in any place as in any sort of little cabin of your own .

sp.speaker: Tommy Nally
sp.p: The tea boiled in a boiler , you should close your eyes drinking it , and ne'er a bit of sugar hardly in it at all . And our curses on them that boil the eggs too hard ! What use is an egg that is hard to any person on earth ? And as to the dinner , what way would a tasty person eat it not having a knife or a fork ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: That I may live to be in no one 's way , but to have some little corner of my own !

sp.speaker: Tommy Nally
sp.p: And to come to your end in it , ma'am ! If you were the Lady Mayor herself you 'd be brought out to the deadhouse if it was ten o'clock at night , and not a wash unless it was just a Scotch lick , and nobody to wake you at all !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I will not go in it ! I would sooner make any shift and die by the side of the wall . Sure heaven is the best place , heaven and this world we 're in now !

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Do n't be giving up now , ma'am . Here is Mr. Nestor coming , and if any one will give you an advice he is the one will do it . Why would n't he , he being , as he is , an educated man , and such a great one to be reading books .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: So he is too , and keeps it in his mind after . It 's a wonder to me a man that does be reading to keep any memory at all .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: It 's easy for him to carry things light , and his pension paid regular at springtime and harvest .

body.stage: Nestor comes in reading “ Tit-Bits . ”

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: There was a servant girl in Austria cut off her finger slicing cabbage ....

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: The poor thing !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: And her master stuck it on again with glue . That now was a very foolish thing to do . What use would a finger be stuck with glue that might melt off at any time , and she to be stirring the pot ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: That is true indeed .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Now , if I myself had been there , it is what I would have advised ....

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: That 's what I was saying , Mr. Nestor . It is you are the grand adviser . What now will you say to poor Mrs. Broderick that has a summons out against her this day for up to ten pounds ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It is what I am often saying , it is a very foolish thing to be getting into debt .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Sure what way could I help it ? It 's a very done-up town to be striving to make a living in .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It would be a right thing to be showing a good example .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: They would want that indeed . There are more die with debts on them in this place than die free from debt .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Many a poor soul has had to suffer from the weight of the debts on him , finding no rest or peace after death .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: The Magistrates are gone into the Courthouse , Mrs. Broderick . Why now would n't you go up to the bank and ask would the manager advance you a loan ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: It is likely he would not do it . But maybe it 's as good for me go as to be sitting here waiting for the end .

body.stage: Puts on hat and shawl .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I now will take charge of the shop for you , Mrs. Broderick .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: It 's little call there 'll be to it . The time a person is sunk that 's the time the custom will go from her .She goes out .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: I 'll be taking a ramble into the Court to see what are the lads doing .Goes out .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Following them .I might chance some customers there myself .

body.stage: Goes out calling — oranges , good oranges .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Taking a paper from his pocket , sitting down , and beginning to read .“ Romantic elopement in high life . A young lady at Aberdeen , Missouri , U. S. A ., having been left by her father an immense fortune .... ”

body.stage: Stops to wipe his spectacles , puts them on again and looks for place , which he has lost . Cooney puts his head in at door and draws it out again .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Come in , come in !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Coming in cautiously and looking round .Whose house now might this be ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: To the Widow Broderick it belongs . She is out in the town presently .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I saw her name up over the door .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: On business of her own she is gone . It is I am minding the place for her .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: So I see . I suppose now you have good cause to be minding it ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It would be a pity any of her goods to go to loss .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I suppose so . Is it to auction them you will or to sell them in bulk ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Not at all . I can sell you any article you will require .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It would be no profit to herself now , I suppose , if you did ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What do you mean saying that ? Do you think I would defraud her from her due in anything I would sell for her at all ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: You are not the bailiff so ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Not at all . I wonder any person to take me for a bailiff !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: You are maybe one of the creditors ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I am not . I am not a man to have a debt upon me to any person on earth .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I wonder what it is you are at so , if you have no claim on the goods . Is it any harm now to ask what 's this your name is ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: One Joseph Nestor I am , there are few in the district but know me . Indeed they all have a great opinion of me . Travelled I did in the army , and attended school and I young , and slept in the one bed with two boys that were learning Greek .

lg.l: : What way now can I be rightly sure that you are Joseph
Nestor ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Pulling out envelope .There is my pension docket . You will maybe believe that .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Examining it .I suppose you may be him so . I saw your name often before this .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Did you now ? I suppose it may have travelled a good distance .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It travelled as far as myself anyway at the bottom of letters that were written asking relief for the owner of this house .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I suppose you are her brother so , Michael Cooney ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: If I am , there are some questions that I want to put and to get answers to before my mind will be satisfied . Tell me this now . Is it a fact Mary Broderick to be living at all ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What would make you think her not to be living and she sending letters to you through the post ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I was saying to myself with myself , there was maybe some other one personating her and asking me to send relief for their own ends .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I am in no want of any relief . That is a queer thing to say and a very queer thing . There are many worse off than myself , the Lord be praised !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Do n't be so quick now starting up to take offence . It is hard to believe the half the things you hear or that will be told to you .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: That may be so indeed ; unless it is things that would be printed on the papers . But I would think you might trust one of your own blood .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I might or I might not . I had it in my mind this long time to come hither and to look around for myself . There are seven generations of the Cooneys trusted nobody living or dead .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Indeed I was reading in some history of one Ulysses that came back from a journey and sent no word before him but slipped in unknown to all but the house dog to see was his wife minding the place , or was she , as she was , scattering his means .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: So she would be too . If Mary Broderick is in need of relief I will relieve her , but if she is not , I will bring away what I brought with me to its own place again .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Sure here is the summons . You can read that , and if you will look out the door you can see by the stir the Magistrates are sitting in the Court . It is a great welcome she will have before you , and the relief coming at the very nick of time .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It is too good a welcome she will give me I am thinking . It is what I am in dread of now , if she thinks I brought her the money so soft and so easy , she will never be leaving me alone , but dragging all I have out of me by little and little .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Maybe you might let her have but the lend of it .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Where 's the use of calling it a lend when I may be sure I never will see it again ? It might be as well for me to earn the value of a charity .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: You might do that and not repent of it .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It is likely I 'll be annoyed with her to the end of my lifetime if she knows I have as much as that to part with . It might be she would be following me to Limerick .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Wait now a minute till I will give you an advice .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It is likely my own advice is the best . Look over your own shoulder and do the thing you think right . How can any other person know the reasons I have in my mind ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I will know what is in your mind if you will tell it to me .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It would suit me best , she to get the money and not to know at the present time where did it come from . The next time she will write wanting help from me , I will task her with it and ask her to give me an account .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: That now would take a great deal of strategy .... Wait now till I think .... I have it in my mind I was reading in a penny novel ... no but on the “ Gael ” ... about a boy of Kilbecanty that saved his old sweetheart from being evicted .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I never heard my sister had any old sweetheart .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It was playing Twenty-five he did it . Played with the husband he did , letting him win up to fifty pounds .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Mary Broderick was no cardplayer . And if she was itself she would know me . And it 's not fifty pounds I am going to leave with her , or twenty pounds , or a penny more than is needful to free her from the summons to-day .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Excited .I will make up a plan ! I am sure I will think of a good one . It is given in to me there is no person so good at making up a plan as myself on this side of the world , not on this side of the world ! I will manage all . Leave here what you have for her before she will come in . I will give it to her in some secret way .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I do n't know . I will not give it to you before I will get a receipt for it ... and I 'll not leave the town till I 'll see did she get it straight and fair . Into the Court I 'll go to see her paying it .

body.stage: Sits down and writes out receipt .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I was reading on “ Home Chat ” about a woman put a note for five pounds into her son 's prayer book and he going a voyage . And when he came back and was in the church with her it fell out , he never having turned a leaf of the book at all .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Let you sign this and you may put it in the prayer book so long as she will get it safe .Nestor signs . Cooney looks suspiciously at signature and compares it with a letter and then gives notes .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Signing .Joseph Nestor .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Let me see now is it the same handwriting I used to be getting on the letters . It is . I have the notes here .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Wait now till I see is there a prayer book ....Looks on shelfTreacle , castor oil , marmalade .... I see no books at all .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Hurry on now , she will be coming in and finding me .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Here is what will do as well .... “ Old Moore 's Almanac . ” I will put it here between the leaves . I will ask her the prophecy for the month . You can come back here after she finding it .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Am n't I after telling you I would n't wish her to have sight of me here at all ? What are you at now , I wonder , saying that . I will take my own way to know does she pay the money . It is not my intention to be made a fool of .

body.stage: Goes out .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: You will be satisfied and well satisfied . Let me see now where are the predictions for the month .Reads .“ The angry appearance of Scorpio and the position of the pale Venus and Jupiter presage much danger for England . The heretofore obsequious Orangemen will refuse to respond to the tocsin of landlordism . The scales are beginning to fall from their eyes . ”

body.stage: Mrs. Broderick comes in without his noticing her . She gives a groan . He drops book and stuffs notes into his pocket .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Here I am back again and no addition to me since I went .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: You gave me a start coming in so noiseless .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: It is time for me go to the Court , and I give you my word I 'd be better pleased going to my burying at the Seven Churches . A nice slab I have there waiting for me , though the man that put it over me I never saw him at all , and he a far off cousin of my own .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Who knows now , Mrs. Broderick , but things might turn out better than you think .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: What way could they turn out better between this and one o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Scratching his head .I suppose now you would n't care to play a game of Twenty-five ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I am surprised at you , Mr. Nestor , asking me to go cardplaying on such a day and at such an hour as this .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I wonder might some person come in and give an order for ten pounds ’ worth of the stock ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Much good it would do me . Sure I have the most of it on credit .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Well , there is no knowing . Some well-to-do person now passing the street might have seen you and taken a liking to you and be willing to make an advance or a loan .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Ah , who would be taking a liking to me as they might to a young girl in her bloom .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Oh , it 's a sort of thing might happen . Sure age did n't catch on to you yet ; you are clean and fresh and sound . What 's this I was reading in “ Answers . ”Looks at it .“ Romantic elopement .... ”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I know of no one would be thinking of me for a wife ... unless it might be yourself , Mr. Nestor ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Jumping up and speaking fast and running finger up and down paper .“ Performance of Dick Whittington . ” ... There now , there is a story that I read in my reading , it was called Whittington and the Cat . It was the cat led to his fortune . There might some person take a fancy to your cat ....

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Ah , let you have done now . I have no cat this good while . I banished it on the head of it threatening the jackdaw .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: The jackdaw ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Fetches cage from inner room .Sure I reared it since the time it fell down the chimney and I going into my bed . It is often you should have seen it , in or out of its cage . Hero his name is . Come out now , Hero .

body.stage: Opens cage .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Slapping his side .That is it ... that 's the very thing . Listen to me now , Mrs. Broderick , there are some might give a good price for that bird .Sitting down to the work .It chances now there is a friend of mine in South Africa . A mine owner he is ... very rich ... but it is down in the mine he has to live by reason of the Kaffirs ... it is hard to keep a watch upon them in the half dark , they being black .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I suppose ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: He does be lonesome now and again , and he is longing for a bird to put him in mind of old Ireland ... but he is in dread it would die in the darkness ... and it came to his mind that it is a custom with jackdaws to be living in chimneys , and that if any birds would bear the confinement it is they that should do it .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: And is it to buy jackdaws he is going ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Is n't that what I am coming to .He pulls out notes .Here now is ten pounds I have to lay out for him . Take them now and good luck go with them , and give me the bird .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Notes is it ? Is it waking or dreaming I am and I standing up on the floor ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Good notes and ten of them . Look at them ! National Bank they are .... Count them now , according to your fingers , and see did I tell any lie .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Counting .They are in it sure enough ... so long as they are good ones and I not made a hare of before the magistrates .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Go out now to the Court and show them to Timothy Ward , and see does he say are they good . Pay them over then , and its likely you will be let off the costs .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Taking shawl .I will go , I will go . Well , you are a great man and a kind man , Joseph Nestor , and that you may live a thousand years for this good deed .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Look here now , ma'am , I would n't wish you to be mentioning my name in this business or saying I had any hand in it at all .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I will not so long as it 's not pleasing to you . Well , it is yourself took a great load off me this day !She goes out .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Calling after her .I might as well be putting the jackdaw back into the cage to be ready for the journey .Comes into shop .I hope now he will be well treated by the sailors and he travelling over the sea .... Where is he now ....Chirrups .Here now , come here to me , what 's this your name is .... Nero ! Nero !Makes pounces behind counter .Ah , bad manners to you , is it under the counter you are gone !

body.stage: Lies flat on the floor chirruping and calling , Nero ! Nero ! Nally comes in and watches him curiously .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Is it catching blackbeetles you are , Mr. Nestor ? Where are they and I will give you a hand ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Getting up annoyed .It 's that bird I was striving to catch a hold of for to put him back in the cage .

sp.speaker: Tommy Nally
sp.p: Making a pounce .There he is now .Puts bird in cage .Wait now till I 'll fasten the gate .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Just putting everything straight and handy for the widow woman I am before she will come back from the settlement she is making in the Court .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: What way will she be able to do that ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I gave her advice . A thought I had , something that came from my reading .Taps paper .Education and reading and going in the army through the kingdoms of the world ; that is what fits a man now to be giving out advice .

sp.speaker: Tommy
sp.p: Indeed , it 's good for them to have you , all the poor ignorant people of this town .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Coming in hurriedly and knocking against Nally as he goes out .What , now , would you say to be the best nesting place in this town . Nests of jackdaws I should say .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: There is the old mill should be a good place . To the west of the station it is . Chimneys there are in it . Middling high they are . Wait now till I 'll tell you of the great plan I made up ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: What are you asking for those rakes in the corner ? It 's no matter , I 'll take one on credit , or maybe it is only the lend of it I 'll take . ... I 'll be coming back immediately .He goes out with rake .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Coming in excitedly .If you went bird-catching , Mr. Nestor , tell me what way would you go doing it ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It is not long since I was reading some account of that ... lads that made a trade of it ... nets they had and they used to be spreading them in the swamps where the plover do be feeding ....

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Ah , sure where 's the use of a plover !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: And snares they had for putting along the drains where the snipe do be picking up worms .... But if I myself saw any person going after things of the sort , it is what I would advise them to stick to the net .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: What now is the price of that net in the corner ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Taking it down .It is but a little bag that is , suitable for carrying small articles ; it would become your oranges well . Twopence I believe , Sibby , is what I should charge you for that .

lg.l: Give it to me so ! Here
I 'll get the start of you , Timothy Ward , anyway .

body.stage: She takes it and goes out , almost overturning Timothy Ward , who is rushing in .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Well , Timothy , did you see the Widow Broderick in the Court ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: I did see her . It is in it she is , now , looking as content as in the coffin , and she paying her debt .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Did she give you any account of herself ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: She did to be sure , and to the whole Court ; but look here now , I have no time to be talking . I have to be back there when the magistrates will have their lunch taken . Now you being so clever a man , Mr. Nestor , what would you say is the surest way to go catching birds ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It is a strange thing now , I was asked the same question not three minutes ago . I was just searching my mind . It seems to me I have read in some place it is a very good way to go calling to them with calls ; made for the purpose they are . You have but to sit under a tree or whatever place they may perch and to whistle ... suppose now it might be for a curlew ....Whistles .

sp.speaker: Timothy Ward
sp.p: Are there any of those calls in the shop ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I would not say there are any made for the purpose , but there might be something might answer you all the same . Let me see now ....Gets down a box of musical toys and turns them over .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Is there anything now has a sound like the croaky screech of a jackdaw ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Here now is what we used to be calling a corncrake ....Turns it .Corncrake , corncrake ... but it seems to me now that to give it but the one creak , this way ... it is much like what you would hear in the chimney at the time of the making of the nests .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Give it here to me !

body.stage: Puts a penny on counter and runs out .

lg.l: For the love of
God , Mr. Nestor , will you give me that live-trap on credit !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: A trap ? Sure there is no temptation for rats to be settling themselves in the Workhouse .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Or a snare itself ... or any sort of a thing that would make the makings of a crib .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What would you want , I wonder , going out fowling with a crib ?

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Why would n't I want it ? Why would n't I have leave to catch a bird the same as every other one ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: And what would the likes of you be wanting with a bird ?

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: What would I want with it , is it ? Why would n't I be getting my own ten pounds ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Heaven help your poor head this day !

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Why would n't I get it the same as Mrs. Broderick got it ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Well , listen to me now . You will not get it .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Sure that man is buying them will have no objection they to come from one more than another .

lg.l: : Do n't be arguing now . It is a queer thing for you , Tommy
Nally , to be arguing with a man like myself .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Think now all the good it would do me ten pound to be put in my hand ! It is not you should be begrudging it to me , Mr. Nestor . Sure it would be a relief upon the rates .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I tell you you will not get ten pound or any pound at all . Ca n't you give attention to what I say ?

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: If I had but the price of the trap you would n't refuse it to me . Well , is n't there great hardship upon a man to be bet up and to have no credit in the town at all .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Exasperated , and giving him the cage .Look here now , I have a right to turn you out into the street . But , as you are silly like and with no great share of wits , I will make you a present of this bird till you try what will you get for it , and till you see will you get as much as will cover its diet for one day only . Go out now looking for customers and maybe you will believe what I say .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Seizing it .That you may be doing the same thing this day fifty years ! My fortune 's made now !Goes out with cage .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Sitting down .My joy go with you , but I 'm bothered with the whole of you . Everyone expecting me to do their business and to manage their affairs . That is the drawback of being an educated man !

body.stage: Takes up paper to read .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Coming in .I declare I 'm as comforted as Job coming free into the house from the Court !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Well , indeed , ma'am , I am well satisfied to be able to do what I did for you , and for my friend from Africa as well , giving him so fine and so handsome a bird .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Sure Finn himself that chewed his thumb had not your wisdom , or King Solomon that kept order over his kingdom and his own seven hundred wives . There is neither of them could be put beside you for settling the business of any person at all .

body.stage: Sibby comes in holding up her netted bag .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What is it you have there , Sibby ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Look at them here , look at them here .... I was n't long getting them . Warm they are yet ; they will take no injury .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: What are they at all ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: It is eggs they are ... look at them . Jackdaws ’ eggs .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Suspiciously .And what call have you now to be bringing in jackdaws ’ eggs ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Is it ten pound apiece I will get for them do you think , or is it but ten pound I will get for the whole of them ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Is it drink , or is it tea , or is it some change that is come upon the world that is fitting the people of this place for the asylum in Ballinasloe ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: I know of a good clocking hen . I will put the eggs under her .... I will rear them when they 'll be hatched out .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I suppose now , Mrs. Broderick , you went belling the case through the town ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I did not , but to the Magistrates upon the bench that I told it out of respect to , and I never mentioned your name in it at all .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Tell me now , Mrs. Broderick , who have I to apply to ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: What is it you are wanting to apply about ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Will you tell me where is the man that is after buying your jackdaw ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Looking at Nestor .What 's that ? Where is he , is it ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Making signs of silence .How would you know where he is ? It is not in a broken little town of this sort such a man would be stopping , and he having his business finished .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Sure he will have to be coming back here for the bird . I will stop till I 'll see him drawing near .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It is more likely he will get it consigned to the shipping agent . Mind what I say now , it is best not be speaking of him at all .

body.stage: Timothy Ward comes in triumphantly , croaking his toy . He has a bird in his hand .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: I chanced on a starling . It was not with this I tempted him , but a little chap that had him in a crib . Would you say now , Mr. Nestor , would that do as well as a jackdaw ? Look now , it 's as handsome every bit as the other . And anyway it is likely they will both die before they will reach to their journey 's end .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Lifting up his hands .Of all the foolishness that ever came upon the world !

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Hurry on now , Mrs. Broderick , tell me where will I bring it to the buyer you were speaking of . He is fluttering that hard it is much if I can keep him in my hand . Is it at Noonan 's Royal Hotel he is or is it at Mack 's ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Shaking his head threateningly .How can you tell that and you not knowing it yourself ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Sure you have a right to know what way did he go , and he after going out of this .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Her eyes apprehensively on Nestor .Ah , sure , my mind was tattered on me . I could n't know did he go east or west . Standing here in this place I was , like a ghost that got a knock upon its head .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: If he is coming back for the bird it is here he will be coming , and if it is to be sent after him it is likely you will have his address .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: So I should , too , I suppose . Where now did I put it ?She looks to Nestor for orders , but cannot understand his signs , and turns out pocket .That 's my specs ... that 's the key of the box ... that 's a bit of root liquorice .... Where now at all could I have left down that address ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: There has no train left since he was here . Sure what does it matter so long as he did not go out of this . I 'll bring this bird to the railway . Tell me what sort was he till I 'll know him .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Still looking at Nestor .Well , he was middling tall ... not very gross ... about the figure now of Mr. Nestor .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: What aged man was he ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I suppose up to sixty years . About the one age , you 'd say , with Mr. Nestor .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Give me some better account now ; it is hardly I would make him out by that .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: A grey beard he has hanging down ... and a bald poll , and grey hair like a fringe around it ... just for all the world like Mr. Nestor !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Jumping up .There is nothing so disagreeable in the whole world as a woman that has too much talk .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Well , let me alone . Where 's the use of them all picking at me to say where did I get the money when I am under orders not to tell it ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Under orders ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I am , and strong orders .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Whose orders are those ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: What 's that to you , I ask you ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Is n't it a pity now a woman to be so unneighbourly and she after getting profit for herself ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Look now , Mr. Nestor , the way they are going on at me , and you saying no word for me at all .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: How would he say any word when he has n't it to say ? The only word could be said by any one is that you are a mean grasping person , gathering what you can for your own profit and keeping yourself so close and so compact . It is back to the Court I am going , and it 's no good friend I 'll be to you from this out , Mrs. Broderick !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Am n't I telling you I was bidden not to tell ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: You were . And is it likely it was you yourself bid yourself and gave you that advice , Mrs. Broderick ? It is what I think the bird was never bought at all . It is in some other way she got the money . Maybe in a way she does not like to be talking of . Light weights , light fingers ! Let us go away so and leave her , herself and her money and her orders !Timothy Ward goes out , but Sibby stops at door .And much good may they do her .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Listen to that , Mr. Nestor ! Will you be listening to that , when one word from yourself would clear my character ! I leave it now between you and the hearers . Why would I be questioned this way and that way , the same as if I was on the green table before the judges ? You have my heart broke between you . It 's best for me to heat the kettle and wet a drop of tea .

body.stage: Goes to inner room .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Tell us the truth now , Mr. Nestor , if you know anything at all about it .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I know everything about it . It was to myself the notes were handed in the first place . I am willing to take my oath to you on that . It was a stranger , I said , came in .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: I wish I could see him and know him if I did see him .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It is likely you would know a man of that sort if you did see him , Sibby Fahy . It is likely you never saw a man yet that owns riches would buy up the half of this town .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: It is not always them that has the most that makes the most show . But it is likely he will have a good dark suit anyway , and shining boots , and a gold chain hanging over his chest .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Sarcastically .He will , and gold rings and pins the same as the King of France or of Spain .

body.stage: Enter Cooney , hatless , streaked with soot and lime , speechless but triumphant . He holds up a nest with nestlings .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What has happened you , Mr. Cooney , at all ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Look now , what I have got !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: A nest , is it ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Three young ones in it !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Faintly .Is it what you are going to say they are jackdaws !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I followed your directions ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: How do you make that out ?

sp.speaker: Caoney
sp.p: You said the mill chimneys were full of them ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What has that to do with it ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I left my rake after me broken in the loft ... my hat went away in the millrace ... I tore my coat on the stones ... there has mortar got into my eye ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: The Lord bless and save us !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: But there is no man can say I did not bring back the birds , sound and living and in good health . Look now , the open mouths of them !All gather round .Three of them safe and living .... I lost one climbing the wall . ... Where now is the man is going to buy them ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Pointing at Nestor .It is he that can tell you that .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Make no delay bringing me to him . I 'm in dread they might die on me first .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: You should know well that no one is buying them .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: No one ! Sure it was you yourself told us that there was !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: If I did itself there is no such a man .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: It 's not above two minutes he was telling of the rings and the pins he wore .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: He never was in it at all .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: What plan is he making up now to defraud me and to rob me ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Question him yourself , and you will see what will he say .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: How can I ask questions of a man that is telling lies ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I am telling no lies . I am well able to answer you and to tell you the truth .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Tell me where is the man that will give me cash for these birds , the same as he gave it to the woman of this house ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: That 's it , that is it . Let him tell it out now .

lg.l: : Will you have me ask it as often as the hairs of my head ? If
I get vexed I will make you answer me .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It seems to me to have set fire to a rick , but I am well able to quench it after . There is no man in South Africa , or that came from South Africa , or that ever owned a mine there at all . Where is the man bought the bird , are you asking ? There he is standing among us on this floor .Points to Cooney .That is himself , the very man !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Advancing a step .What is that you are saying ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I say that no one came in here but yourself .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Did he say or not say there was a rich man came in ?

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: He did , surely .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: To make up a plan ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I know well you have made up a plan .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: To give it unknownst ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It is to keep it unknownst you are wanting !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: The way she would not suspect ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It is I myself suspect and have cause to suspect ! Give me back my own ten pounds and I 'll be satisfied .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What way can I give it back ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: The same way as you took it , in the palm of your hand .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Sure it is paid away and spent ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: If it is you 'll repay it ! I know as well as if I was inside you you are striving to make me your prey ! But I 'll sober you ! It is into the Court I will drag you , and as far as the gaol !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I tell you I gave it to the widow woman ....

body.stage: Mrs. Broderick comes in .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Let her say now did you .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: What is it at all ? What is happening ? Joseph Nestor threatened by a tinker or a tramp !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I would think better of his behaviour if he was a tinker or a tramp .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: He has drink taken so . Is n't drink the terrible tempter , a man to see flames and punishment upon the one side and drink upon the other , and to turn his face towards the drink !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Will you stop your chat , Mary Broderick , till I will drag the truth out of this traitor ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Who is that calling me by my name ? Och ! Is it Michael Cooney is in it ? Michael Cooney , my brother ! O Michael , what will they think of you coming into the town and much like a rag on a stick would be scaring in the wheatfield through the day ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Pointing at Nestor .It was going up in the mill I destroyed myself , following the directions of that ruffian !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: And what call has a man that has drink taken to go climbing up a loft in a mill ? A crooked mind you had always , and that 's a sort of person drink does n't suit .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I tell you I did n't take a glass over a counter this ten year .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: You would do well to go learn behaviour from Mr. Nestor .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: The man that has me plundered and robbed ! Tell me this now , if you can tell it . Did you find any pound notes in “ Old Moore 's Almanac ” ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I did not to be sure , or in any other place .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: She came in at the door and I striving to put them into the book .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Look are they in it now , and I will say he is not tricky , but honest .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: You need n't be looking ....

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Turning over the leaves .Ne'er a thing at all in it but the things that will or will not happen , and the days of the changes of the moon .

lg.l: Look at that now !
Will you believe me now telling you that you are a rogue ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Will you listen to me , ma'am ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: No , but listen to myself . I brought the money to you .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: If he did he would n't trust you with it , ma'am .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I intended it for your relief .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: In dread he was you would go follow him to Limerick .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: It is not likely I would be following the like of him to Limerick , a man that left me to the charity of strangers from Africa !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I gave the money to him ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: And I gave it to yourself paying for the jackdaw . Are you satisfied now , Mary Broderick ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Satisfied , is it ? It would be a queer thing indeed I to be satisfied . My brother to be spending money on birds , and his sister with a summons on her head . Michael Cooney to be passing himself off as a mine-owner , and I myself being the way I am !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: What would I want doing that ? I tell you I ask no birds , black , blue or white !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: I wonder at you now saying that , and you with that clutch on your arm !Cooney indignantly flings away nest .Searching out jackdaws and his sister without the price of a needle in the house ! I tell you , Michael Cooney , it is yourself will be wandering after your burying , naked and perishing , through winds and through frosts , in satisfaction for the way you went wasting your money and your means on such vanities , and she that was reared on the one floor with you going knocking at the Workhouse door ! What good will jackdaws be to you that time ?

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It is what I would wish to know , what scheme are the whole of you at ? It is long till I will trust any one but my own eyes again in the whole of the living world .

body.stage: She wipes her eyes indignantly . Tommy Nally rushes in the bird and cage still in his hands .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Where is the bird buyer ? It is here he is said to be . It is well for me get here the first . It is the whole of the town will be here within half an hour ; they have put a great scatter on themselves hunting and searching in every place , but I am the first !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: What is it you are talking about ?

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Not a house in the whole street but is deserted . It is much if the Magistrates themselves did n't quit the bench for the pursuit , the way Tim Ward quitted the place he had a right to be !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: It is some curse in the air , or some scourge ?

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Birds they are getting by the score ! Old and young ! Where is the bird-buyer ? Who is it now will give me my price ?

body.stage: He holds up the cage .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: There is surely some root for all this . There must be some buyer after all . It 's to keep him to themselves they are wanting .Goes to door .But I 'll get my own profit in spite of them .

body.stage: He goes outside door , looking up and down the street .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Look at what Tommy Nally has . That 's my bird .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: It is not , it 's my own !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: That is my cage !

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: It is not , it is mine !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Would n't I know my own cage and my own bird ? Do n't be telling lies that way !

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: It is no lie I am telling . The bird and the cage were made a present to me .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Who would make a present to you of the things that belong to myself ?

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: It was Mr. Nestor gave them to me .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Do you hear what he says , Joseph Nestor ? What call have you to be giving a present of my bird ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: And was n't I after buying it from you ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: If you were it was not for yourself you bought it , but for the poor man in South Africa you bought it , and you defrauding him now , giving it away to a man has no claim to it at all . Well , now , is n't it hard for any man to find a person he can trust ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Did n't you hear me saying I bought it for no person at all ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Give it up now , Tommy Nally , or I 'll have you in gaol on the head of it .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Oh , you would n't do such a thing , ma'am , I am sure !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Indeed and I will , and have you on the treadmill for a thief .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Oh , oh , oh , look now , Mr. Nestor , the way you have made me a thief and to be lodged in the gaol !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I wish to God you were lodged in it , and we would have less annoyance in this place !

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Oh , that is a terrible thing for you to be saying ! Sure the poorhouse itself is better than the gaol ! The nuns preparing you for heaven and the Mass every morning of your life ....

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: If you go on with your talk and your arguments it 's to gaol you will surely go .

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: Milk of a Wednesday and a Friday , the potatoes steamed very good .... It 's the skins of the potatoes they were telling me you do have to be eating in the gaol . It is what I am thinking , Mr. Nestor , that bird will lie heavy on you at the last !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Seizing cage and letting the bird out of the door .Bad cess and a bad end to it , and that I may never see it or hear of it again !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Look what he is after doing ! Get it back for me ! Give it here into my hands I say ! Why would n't I sell it secondly to the buyer and he to be coming to the door ? It is in my own pocket I will keep the price of it that time !

sp.speaker: Nally
sp.p: It would have been as good you to have left it with me as to be sending itself and the worth of it up into the skies !

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: Taking Nestor 's arm .Get it back for me I tell you ! There it is above in the ash tree , and it flapping its wings on a bough !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Give me the cage , if that will content you , and I will strive to entice it to come in .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Coming in .Everyone running this way and that way . It is for birds they are looking sure enough . Why now would they go through such hardship if there was not a demand in some place ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Pushing him away .Let me go now before that bird will quit the branch where it is .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Seizing hold of him .Is it striving to catch a bird for yourself you are now ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Let me pass if you please . I have nothing to say to you at all .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Laying down to me they were worth nothing ! I knew well you had made up some plan ! The grand adviser is it ! It is to yourself you gave good advice that time !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Let me out I tell you before that uproar you are making will drive it from its perch on the tree .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Is it to rob me of my own money you did and to be keeping me out of the money I earned along with it !

body.stage: Threatens Nestor with “ Moore 's Almanac , ” which he has picked up .

sp.speaker: Sibby
sp.p: Take care would there be murder done in this place !

body.stage: She seizes Nestor , Mrs. Broderick seizes Cooney . Tommy Nally wrings his hands .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Tommy Nally , will you kindly go and call for the police .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Is it into a den of wild beasts I am come that must go calling out for the police ?

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: A very unmannerly person indeed !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Everyone thinking to take advantage of me and to make their own trap for my ruin .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: I do n't know what cause has he at all to have taken any umbrage against me .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: You that had your eye on my notes from the first like a goat in a cabbage garden !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Coming with a gift in the one hand and holding a dagger in the other !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: If you say that again I will break your collar bone !

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: O , but you are the terrible wicked man !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: I 'll squeeze satisfaction out of you if I had to hang for it ! I will be well satisfied if I 'll kill you !

body.stage: Flings “ Moore 's Almanac ” at him .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Throwing his bundle of newspapers .Oh , good jewel !

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Coming in hastily .Whist the whole of you , I tell you ! The Magistrates are coming to the door !Comes in and shuts it after him .

sp.speaker: Mrs. Broderick
sp.p: The Lord be between us and harm ! What made them go quit the Court ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: The whole of the witnesses and of the prosecution made off bird-catching . The Magistrates sent to invite the great mine-owner to go lunch at Noonan 's with themselves .

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Horses of their own to stick him with they have . I would n't doubt them at all .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: He could not be found in any place . They are informed he was never seen leaving this house . They are coming to make an investigation .

sp.speaker: Nestor
sp.p: Do n't be anyway uneasy . I will explain the whole case .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: The police along with them ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: Is the whole of this district turned into a trap ?

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: It is what they are thinking , that the stranger was made away with for his gold !

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: And if he was , as sure as you are living , it was done by that blackguard there !

body.stage: Points at Nestor .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: If he is not found they will arrest all they see upon the premises ....

sp.speaker: Cooney
sp.p: It is best for me to quit this .

body.stage: Goes to door .

sp.speaker: Ward
sp.p: Here they are at the door . Sergeant Carden along with them . Hide yourself , Mr. Nestor , if you 've anyway to do it at all .
